title: Introduction to Japanese Studies I
description: This course provides basic training for doing research in Japanese studies, and gives a general introduction of Japanese society, culture, history, economy, etc.Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors only.
outcome: (1) Students are expected to be able to critically discuss Japanese society through the lens of social stratification, education, work organization, gender, history and ethnic identity.    (2) Students are expected to be able to clarify and articulate thoughtful and well founded opinions in a comparative context related to Japanese society.   (3) Students are expected to develop their research skills through a short in-term research project that includes a written assignment and oral presentation.   (4) Students are introduced to a variety of research methodologies such as text analysis, public discourse analysis, qualitative methodology including interviewing skills etc.   (5) Students are expected to develop the ability to engage critically in academic discussions through weekly contributions to a blog, an in-class presentation using video and power point technologies.

title: Field Research Methods
description: This course aims to provide students with an understanding of basic research methods for independent field research. Research methods such as interviewing, questionnaires, participant observation, and media surveys will be introduced and the merits of each will be discussed. The course will teach students how to design a research project and write a research proposal. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors only.
outcome: Students will gain an understanding of the merits and limitations of a variety of qualitative research methods. Students will be able apply selected social science methodology to design their own research project in Japan.

title: Understanding Japan
requirements: Not for students who have taken JASP1020.
description: The course introduces students to major social and cultural issues in present-day Japan. It explores the important debates, problems, and challenges that have shaped Japanese society and culture in recent decades. The course encourages students to think critically about issues in Japanese society from a variety of disciplinary perspectives.
outcome: -state, recognize, recall and tell the main features of postwar Japan. Participants are expected to analyze the challenges faced by postwar and contemporary Japan and how they were surmounted successfully. -recognize, describe and clarify the strengths and weaknesses, the advantages and disadvantages of the features and characteristics of contemporary Japan. -compare and contrast Japanese developmental phases in the postwar years.  -apply, relate and deepen their appreciation of the significance of the dynamics and interaction of selected Japanese political, social, environmental, demographic developments. Deepen their appreciation of the significance of major developments within Japan. Deepen their appreciation of the significance of the dynamics of Japan’s domestic society, economy and politics; its interaction with its neighboring region and the rest of the world; examine Japan’s coping mechanisms in interacting with globalization and major recent world trends.  -analyze Japan's structure, policies, economy, society and current trends. Analyze the causes and effects of internal and external influences on Japan's development. Analyze the challenges that Japan faces, its ways of managing them and the resulting innovative features. Develop analytical frameworks for these analyses. -generalize, reflect and hypothesize their own conclusions with regards to the course materials and contemporary issues  [Writing skills] Through the graded short essay exercise required in the course, class participants develop skills in essay-writing and library research such as literature review and analytical skills. It is also an opportunity for participants to put their creative ideas in writing.   [Interactive skills] Class participation and attendance facilitates interactions with other class participants, learning from each other and exploring alternative viewpoints. The graded tutorials enhances interactions with other class participants, learning from each other and exploring alternative viewpoints through oral presentations that include class discussions and debates. Subject to availability, guest lectures may also be possible as opportunities for class participants to interact with individuals with specific relevant expertise.   [Reading skills] While lectures and tutorials are the main modes of knowledge exchange and learning activity, students are encouraged to critically examine the required readings and present their alternative viewpoints and comments in the tutorials.

description: (UGEC1232 is double-coded with JASP1100.) The main objective of this course is to give students a general idea of Japanese cultural history and social background of modern Japan. Guidance leading to a better understanding of Japan will be provided.
outcome: 1) Students are expected to gain an understanding of the main areas of Japanese life including work, family, gender roles, marriage, and religion. They are expected to understand the ways in which Japanese see their own society in terms of economic growth, Japan's place in the world, social order, and political structure.   2) Students are expected to understand and be able to use a variety of social theories and perspectives in understanding Japan. They are also expected to have gained an understanding of how these same perspectives might be used to analyze their own society, or other societies which they may wish to study in the future.   3) Students are expected to develop a clearer understanding of their own values regarding work, leisure, marriage, family, love, and religion through a comparison with the debates and competing interpretations of these values in Japan.     Remarks: Department Board members disagreed with the suggestion that they replace the word 'understanding' with another word such as 'identity, explain, analyze or synthesize' as suggested by UGE.

It considers how and why these images have changed over time and asks students to consider the usefulness and limits of generalizations about other people and societies.   Week 2: Nation, Nationalism and the Imperial System This lesson introduces students to theories explaining nationalism. It then uses these theories to consider nationalism in Japan. It explores the Japanese Imperial system in the context of historical developments in Japanese nationalism. Read:   1)   Akemi Nakamura. title: Understanding Japanese Languages and Culture
description: (UGEC1281 is double-coded with JASP1120.) This course explores the relationship between Japanese language and culture. Everyday communication strategies adopted by people in Japanese society will be examined in terms of Japanese language expressions, styles and structures. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course but interdisciplinary approaches will also be adopted. This course is designed for students who are interested in knowing more about Japan but who have very limited or no knowledge of the Japanese language. Student will gain an understanding of the basic structure of the Japanese language, learn how usage of the language reflects Japanese culture and behavior, and explore how communication patterns of Japanese speakers differ from speakers of other languages.
outcome: 1. Students are expected to have gained a basic understanding of the structure of the Japanese language and historical changes of the writing system. Moreover, students will be able to understand the usage of the language, different styles and when each should be used, and different strategies used in expressing politeness. 2. Students are expected to understand the relationship between the language expressions and the behaviors of Japanese people in various circumstances and the reasons behind such behaviors. 3. Through comparing the culture of Japan with that of Hong Kong, students will become able to make comments on the characteristics of each and distinguish between the two. 4. Students will be able to perform an elementary study regarding Japanese culture and this will help the students to develop his/her further study in Japanese Studies.
syllabus: Week 1 Lesson 1 Introduction to Japanese culture: This lesson explains how Japanese culture influences daily life in Hong Kong today. The usage and the characteristics of Japanese language will also be discussed.   Week 2 Lesson 2 Introduction to the historical changes of kanji and kana in the Japanese language: This lesson explains the historical changes of kanji and kana in Japanese language. Focus will be on why Japanese absorbed Chinese characters into their writing system and the process of how Chinese characters were converted to the modern kana (hiragana and katakana).   Week 3 – Week 4 Lesson 3 Introduction to the phrases expressing linguistic politeness: This lesson briefly explains the phrases expressing linguistic politeness. These include honorific expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.   Week 4 - 5 Lesson 4 Strategies used in making requests and refusals in Japanese:  This lesson discusses how Japanese make requests and refuse the requests of others. Such expressions are often used in daily life by Japanese but are not easily understood by foreigners. Special attention will be given to:  a. the difference in behaviour between Japanese and non Japanese in making requests and refusals. b. how this behaviour reflects characteristics of Japanese culture.    Week 6 – Week 7 Lesson 5 Strategies used in making apologies and taking responsibility: This lesson discusses how Japanese apologize and take responsibility after misconduct such as scandals or accidents. For example, we often see the top management of Japanese companies bow to the public to apologize for their misconduct and they may even quit the company in order to take responsibility for problems. In Hong Kong, it is rare to see such a phenomenon. We will discuss the mechanism of how Japanese make an apology and the effect of the Japanese way of apologizing upon social situations. Special attention will be given to the comparison of the styles of apology in Japanese and Hong Kong societies. We will also discuss the relationship between the Japanese way of apologizing and issues related to the Sino-Japanese War.   Week 8 – Week 9 Lesson 6 Ambiguity in the Javanese language: Compared with other languages such as Chinese, there are many ambiguous linguistic practices in Japanese. These include, for example, the deletion of the subject "watashi" (I), the use of "koto ni narimashita" (become something) rather than "koto ni shimashita" (I decided to do something) when talking about personal matters such as getting married, and the frequent use of intransitive verbs rather than transitive verbs. Most Japanese language learners including Hong Kong learners have experienced difficulties with these expressions and practices in their learning process. We will analyze and comment on this phenomenon.   Week 9 – Week 10 Lesson 7 The Business Manner of Japanese: This lesson discusses how Japanese behave in business negotiations. Japanese are often criticized for not stating their true feelings and opinions. They often use expressions such as "kangaesasetekudasai" (Please let me think about it), "kekkoo desu" (It's O.K. /No, thank you) to indirectly express their opinions. We will discuss why Japanese behave in such a way and the correct way to deal with a Japanese business partner.   Week 10 - Week 11  Lesson 8 Japanese language in a sociolinguistic perspective: In this lesson we discuss the following items of importance in sociolinguistics as they appear in the Japanese language. a. the comparison between written and colloquial styles b. the comparison of language usage for men and women c. the comparison between the standard language and dialect d. the comparison of language usage between the young and the elderly e. the comparison between formal styles and informal styles f. the comparison between jargon and standard expressions   Week 12 Lesson 9 The success and failure in learning Javanese language (with a focus on Hong Kong Cantonese speaking learners): First, we will give a brief introduction to the theories of second language acquisition. Next, the factors affecting the results of the process of second language learning will be discussed. To ensure a better understanding, case studies comparing English language acquisition among Japanese and Hong Kong people will be introduced. Finally, by summarizing the above observations and the characteristics of both Japanese and Cantonese, we will comment on the difficulties experienced by Hong Kong Cantonese speaking Japanese learners.   Week 13 Lesson 10 Special topics on Japanese 1anguage and Japanese culture:  Special topics will be selected to help students understand the relationship between Japanese language and culture. a. title: Chinese-Japanese-Korean Movies: Appreciation and Comparison
requirements: Not for students who have taken GESC2080 or UGEC1293
description: (UGEC1293 is double-coded with JASP1130.)  With the growing popularity of Asian movies in the 1990s, Japan's collaborations and interactions with its neighbors - China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea - have become a major research topic among scholars in the fields of film studies, cultural studies, anthropology and Asian studies. Moreover, cross-border film studies have become an important avenue of understanding globalization. It is within such context that this course aims to expose students to a global perspective for understanding movies of China (including Hong Kong and Taiwan), Japan and Korea by comparing some common themes represented in movies of these countries. This course consists of four major parts focusing on the comparative studies of Chinese, Japanese and Korean cinemas: (1) Nostalgia in Romantic Movies, (2) Historical Trauma in Violent Movies, (3) Images of Women in Women-Centered Films, and (4) Urban Images in Movies Based on Cities. These themes are chosen for their significances of reflecting the recent history of colonization or decolonization, and the experience of modernization in these East Asian societies. Through the above comparative studies, students will learn how different cultures maintain their uniqueness in an era of globalization; and how these topics have been differently interpreted and visualized by the post-war generation of each region. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. The lecturer will commence each lesson by referring to academic readings, and show film clips if necessary, to serve as the basis for in-class discussions.

description: (UGEC1302 is double-coded with JASP1140.) Film is always regarded as an important medium for understanding society and culture. This course consists of two major parts: 1) Lesson 2 to Lesson 7: Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies; 2) Lesson 8 to Lesson 12: Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. title: Japanese Popular Culture in Cultural Globalization
requirements: Not for students who have taken JASP1110 or UGEC1271
description: (UGEC1271 is double-coded with JASP1160.)  This course examines the development and academic significance of various forms of Japanese popular culture such as films, comics, music, TV dramas and culinary culture, from multidisciplinary perspectives, including history, cultural anthropology, cultural studies and media studies. It aims to deepen understanding the following three facets of Japanese popular culture:1) the applicaton of cultural globalization theory in Japan; 2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries; and 3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Using concrete examples and grounding on representative academic writings, this course discusses the globalization of Japanese popular culture and relevant issues in indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows and media-mix. Students are trained to understand the nature and cultural implications of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context. Besides lectures, discussions and readings, this course selectively utilizes topical essays (projects), e-learning, audio-visual materials and fieldwork-based assignments as supplementary teaching tools.
outcome: Through a historical and cultural analysis of different facets of Japanese popular culture, this course aims to achieve the following three academic goals:1)      It aims to use Japanese popular culture as a medium or stepping stone to enhance students’ interest in and understanding of Japanese history, society and culture.2)      It aims to deepen understanding of nature and impact of Japanese cultural industry and its cultural implications in an Asian context.3)      It aims to discuss Japanese popular culture within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. Having taken this course, students will be equipped with a basic ability to analyse cultural phenomenon in the lens of such cultural concepts as indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows, media mix, cultural colonialism and orientalism.
syllabus: Main Objective:This main purpose of course is to examine the global popularization and localization of Japanese popular culture from historical, cultural and comparative perspectives within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. It aims to indicate that the cultural flows between Japan and Asia are by no means one-way traffic and Asia has been interacting and collaborating with the Japanese in creating, manufacturing, marketing and distributing cultural products for decades. Lectures, discussions and readings highlight different facets of cultural acculturation and transnational interaction found in Japan-Asia cross-cultural flows, such as appropriation, hybridization, global localization business strategy, the making of localized editions, the local application of Japanese formula, joint production, and the participation of foreign artists and staff. Solidly grounding on empirical data as well as theories from cultural globalization and cross-cultural studies, this course will be a pioneering teaching and learning project to explore uncharted research territories in Japanese studies, Japan-Hong Kong relations, and cultural studies. Key Issues and Problems:The following key issues and problems regarding the globalization of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context will be addressed in this course within the theoretical fiarnework of cultural globalization: 1) The idea that the influx of Japanese cultural products is a form of cultural imperialism that aims to expand Japanese economic interest and to spread Japanese value and lifestyle in Asia will be empirically and theoretically reexamined and challenged. It shows that cultural imperialism is an outdated model in cross-cultural studies, because it fails to understand the dynamic mechanism in transnational cultural flows and cultural forces of localization and hybridization.2) While using "glocalization" (Roland Robertson uses it to refer to the localization strategy employed by multi-national companies to promote their products in different nations) to investigate the global business strategy of Japanese companies such as Sony, Nintendo, Capcom and Bandai in Asian and global markets, this course underscores the limitation of the glocalization theory in the East Asian context, as it fails to see the initiative taken by Asian artists and businessmen to creatively and selectively domesticate Japanese elements.3) This course uses Japanese popular culture as a mirror or text to decode social and cultural issues of contemporary Japan. For examples, themes about ethnicity, gender, social hierarchy, political ideology, and cultural identity will be examined in the lens of Japanese popular culture. Core Content, Structure and Selected Topics:The course content of this course investigates the three facets of Japanese popular culture: (1) the application of cultural globalization theory in Japan, (2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries, (3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. title: The Japanese Environment: Destruction and Conservation
description: (UGEC1311 is double-coded with JASP1170.)  This course examines central issues in the management of human-environment relations in Japan. As one of the most advanced economies in the world and the first Asian country to have successfully modernized, Japan has experienced severe environmental degradation caused by the irresponsible use of technology but has also developed sophisticated technologies and practices for environmental protection. A critical assessment of the Japanese experience of ecological disaster and environmental conservation offers a useful platform for examining the pitfalls of development and the possibility of sustainable growth in other parts of the world.

title: Modern Sino-Japanese Relations
description: Sino-Japanese relations are an important dimension of the history of modern East Asia. This course analyzes this multifaceted relationship from the mid-19th century to the present day. It will pay special attention to such topics as mutual perception, territorial and historical disputes, immigration, boycotts and collaboration, cultural diplomacy, postwar rapprochement, and attempts to move into a new age of Sino-Japanese coexistence. A main theme of discussion will be the need for accommodation and cooperation despite continual tension between the two countries.
outcome: 學生完成本科目後，將能：  1. 從多角度理解19世紀中葉至今中、日兩國在政治、外交、經濟、軍事、民間社會、教育及文化等方面的關係的起伏發展，以及兩國關係對東亞地區發展的重要性；  2. 掌握有關現代中、日兩國關係的基本概念、知識及理論，如華僑和日僑的形成與發展、中國留日學生的活動、中國人的反日、附日活動、日本對華文化教育政策、兩國相互認識之變化、兩國間的多種糾紛，以及中國威脅論、中國機遇論等重要輿論的產生等；  3. 全面了解中、日兩國在各個方面的衝突和協作關係，尤其明白各領域的關係彼此影響互動的複雜性；  4. 透過參觀在香港日本國總領事館或在港日本文化宗教團體，認識日本官方對華的立場和政策，以及在華日本民間團體的多元化活動；  5. 透過講授課堂尤其導修課堂，養成研習中、日兩國關係的比較視野和批判分析思維，如評估中、日文獻中有關證據或事例在多少程度上說明兩國關係的某(些)方面，或檢查近人著作中的事例能否證明作者的論點；  6. 就現代中、日兩國關係的重要課題，參考各種文獻資料和近人著作，撰寫具邏輯性、連貫性及創意的評論短文；  7. 自行蒐集和分析有關中、日兩國關係的資訊，由此客觀地展望兩國關係的演進發展。  Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. comprehend the development of Sino-Japanese relations in the aspects of politics, diplomacy, economic and military affairs, society, education and culture since the mid19 century and the importance of the relations to East Asia in multiple perspectives   2. master the basic concepts, knowledge and theories of modern Sino-Japanese relations including the evolution of the Chinese society in Japan and the Japanese society in China, the Chinese students’ activities in Japan, the Chinese resistance and collaboration with the Japanese, the Japanese cultural and education policy towards China, the mutual perception and disputes between the Chinese and the Japanese, and the theories of ‘China Threat’ and ‘China Opportunity’, etc;   3. thoroughly understand the conflicts and collaborations between China and Japan in different aspects and especially their interwoven interaction;  4. comprehend the standpoint and policy of the Japanese government towards China and various activities of the Japanese private organizations in China particularly by visiting Consulate-General of Japan or other cultural and religious organizations in Hong Kong;   5. develop comparative perspective and critical and analytical thinking on various aspects of modern Sino-Japanese relations, such as evaluating how far the evidence or examples in the Chinese and Japanese sources illustrate particular aspect(s) of Sino-Japanese relations, and checking whether they substantiate the writer’s claims;  6. write logical, coherent and creative essay on important issue(s) of modern Sino-Japanese relations based on different sources and recent studies;  7. collect and analyze various data about Sino-Japanese relations to look into the future relations objectively.
syllabus: 1. 德川時代在日之華人 (The Chinese in Tokugawa Japan)  本課探討德川時代日本華僑社會形成的背景、因素及過程，又考察長崎華僑融入日本社會，改變居住生活形態的發展，以及中國儒學對德川時期二元政治體制盛衰之影響。  2. 明治、大正時代在日之華人 (The Chinese in Meiji and Taisho Japan)  本課分析19世紀末即明治後期中國人留學日本潮流產生的背景、因素及具體情況，並探究大正時代留日潮流的反覆發展，以及留日學生的政治化趨勢。   3. 中日甲午戰爭 (1894-1895) (The First Sino-Japanese War 1894-1895)  本課分析甲午戰爭爆發的背景和始末、戰爭期間及以後清朝對日觀念的變化，以及戰後的中日關係 發展。   4. 在清朝民國之日本人 (The Japanese in Qing and Republican China)  本課探討甲午戰爭前日本人在華的情報活動和戰爭前後日本人在華經營的通信報刊活動。  5. 日本對華之文教政策 (The Japanese Cultural and Education Policy towards China)  本課考察近代日本在華文教活動的產生及發展、各種教育活動的內容，以及二次大戰期間日本在學校推行的同化教育。  6. 華人的反日與附日 (The Chinese Resistance and Collaboration with the Japanese)  本課一方面探討民初、五四運動時期中國教科書的反日思想、1928年五三慘案以後的反日運動，另一方面分析抗日戰爭期間附日勢力出現的原因，諸勢力的類型、活動以及日本招攬漢奸的政策。  7. 二戰後在日之華人I (The Chinese in Postwar Japan I)  本課探討二次大戰以後至今日本華僑的人數增長情況、中華街華僑的經濟事業發展，以及新一代華僑的經濟結構變化。  8. 二戰後在日之華人II (The Chinese in Postwar Japan II)  本課考察二次大戰以後至今日本新舊數代華僑的不同程度同化情況，又探討 戰後華僑學校的教育問題及華僑的婚姻觀念演變。  9. 駐華之日本外交官 (The Japanese Diplomat on China)  本課說明駐華日本國總領事館包括在香港日本國總領事館的主要角色，指出日本領事充當促進中、日溝通、深化兩國關係的橋樑，並以近來數任在香港日本國總領事的訪問和演講，揭示近來日本的對華政策。  10. 中日的相互理解 (Mutual Perception between the Chinese and the Japanese)  本課考察在近、現代各階段中、日兩國的相互認識和觀感的演變發展及其諸發展跟兩國政治、外交、經濟、軍事等方面變化的互動關係，並探討近年中日兩國致力構築相互認識的平台的趨勢。  11. 日本與中國威脅論 (Japan and the ‘China Threat’ Theory)  本課考察1980年代至今中國的急速經濟發展及經貿策略演變，並分析90年代以來東亞國家經貿分工結構的轉變、中國跟東亞諸國尤其日本的經貿關係發展，以及日本先後產生「中國威脅論」和「中國機會論」的輿論變化。  12. 中日糾紛 (Sino-Japanese Disputes)  本課分析1990年代以來影響中、日兩國關係的國際環境和日本國內環境的種種變化，以及損害兩國關係的若干因素，包括日本政治右傾化問題、兩國的歷史觀衝突、靖國神社參拜問題、新「日美防衛合作指針」及台灣問題等等。  13. 中日關係的前景 (The future of Sino-Japanese Relations)  本課探討中、日兩國在亞洲地區共同化解衝突，協作發展的前景，如共同維持東亞地區的和諧穩定，促進該區的經濟互惠合作、安全和平及災難處理等發展方向。

title: New Practical Japanese I
description: This course provides basic training in the Japanese language. Emphasis is placed on sentence pattern practice and basic grammar. It also includes oral drills, simple compositions, dictation, translation and reading. This course starts from the writing system and basic pronunciation. Course textbooks, course exercise books, examination papers and other course materials are written in Chinese and Japanese. Students taking this course are expected to have prior knowledge in the Chinese language. Advisory: Not for Japanese Studies Majors.
outcome: 1. use verbs of state (iru, aru), directional verbs (kuru, iku, kaeru) , and activity verbs (taberu, nomu, and benkyoosuru).  2. count and use appropriate quantifiers.  3. use na-adjectives and i-adjectives, and be able to conjugate according to the given situation.  4. use past and present tense, and continuous and resultative aspect appropriately.  5. use purpose expressions, such as V+ni.  6. use direct and indirect speech  7. ask when one doesn’t know how to read and what to say (~nan to iimasuka ~doo omoimasuka)  8. use secondary aspect of ~te aru  9. use particles of wa, ga, ni, de, and o.  10. speak with correct pronunciation.
syllabus: JAS1450 and 1460 are consecutive one-semester courses designed to provide comprehensive training in reading, listening, speaking and writing in Japanese at the elementary level for elective students with an emphasis on elementary grammar.  Students are required to attend four hours of language lessons per week and are expected to spend two hours on homework each week. Language lessons are conducted in four languages: Japanese, English, Cantonese and Mandarin. Teachers use various kinds of conversational practices based on natural conversation emphasizing the use of the language in context.  The examination papers are written in Chinese and Japanese, and it contains task(s) of Chinese to Japanese translation. Depending on the situation, an English translation of the Chinese texts can be provided for reference. However, in case there is any inconsistency or conflict in the translation between the Chinese and English texts, the Chinese version shall prevail.   After completing the courses, students are expected to reach novice-middle level, and continue to enrol in the intermediate level language courses.

title: Cultures of Love in Modern Japan
description: In contemporary Japanese society, rules and guidelines govern discourses and practices of romance and affection. This course discusses how ideas from contemporary Japanese popular cultural texts (comics, novels, television dramas, nonfiction guidebooks, websites, social networking services, and others) influence the thinking and culture of human beings. The course also explores how the rules and styles of love are continuously modified, negotiated, and performed, particularly in an urban context. Further, the course considers the metamorphosis of intimacy and how this affects life in the postmodern era. Students are expected to gain a deeper understanding of the nature of love in Japanese culture and how concepts of love influence urban life.

title: Gender and Sexuality in Japan
description: This course introduces the social scientific study of gender, sexuality, and family in Japan from the postwar to the contemporary period from a comparative perspective. As the course covers a lot of readings, writings, and discussions on the issues of gender and sexuality, students are expected to come to class prepared to discuss the readings and facilitate the class discussion. For many, Japan represents a sweeping stereotype of extreme gender norms vis-à-vis contemporary Euro-American gender norms and manifestations. Such stereotypes are employed not only by outsiders to critique the society ethnocentrically, but also by some natives as well. Both sides frequently comment on the ways gender and gendered expectations shape and even determine contemporary experiences of “being Japanese.” Furthermore, stereotypes about gender and sexuality in Japan frequently overlap with and draw from broader stereotypes about Japan vis-à-vis other Asian societies and Asian societies vis-à-vis Western societies.By identifying these stereotypes and also critically questioning what gender means and how it is being shaped in and shaping contemporary Japan, this course will offer an entry into theories of gender studies and sexuality, and also introduce tools to critically analyze cultural differences manifested in the issues of gender and sexuality while at the same time learning more about Japanese society and your own society. Moving between historical and contemporary definitions of gender, sexuality, and family to look at change and continuity of gendered life ways in Japan, the course is divided into five sections addressing issues of: 1) Defining Gender and Gender Stereotypes; 2) Gender and Social Institutions; 3) Gender Construction / Performance; 4) The Politics of Sexuality and Identity; and 5) Gender and “Marginality.” In each section we investigate cultural constructions of gender, sexuality, and family and key themes that revolve around them: identity, class, morality and life course in contemporary Japan. At the end of each section we will take time to reflect on gender and sexuality in Asia more broadly. Class sessions will consist of lecture sessions devoted to explaining the readings in context and tutorial sections for facilitating active discussions and student presentations. Assignments for the course will ask students for active participation and weekly discussion questions, a reflective mid-term essay, and a final exam.

Because of the success of Japanese economic development, Japanese management has become a unique and important field by itself. While Japanese management was much emulated in the 1980s and 1990s, it has also adapted and evolved according to chronological phases in its development. Changing Japanese economic needs, demographic shifts and evolving trends/lifestyles/habits seem to push Japanese management into a creative knowledge-based phase which is covered in the last section of this course. title: Japanese Literature
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a historical outline of Japanese literature. Major works and writers of different periods will be introduced through Chinese/English translation or the original works if students possess sufficient Japanese reading ability.

title: Japan's International Relations
description: This course examines the making of Japanese foreign policy and diplomatic initiatives from the early postwar period to the present from historical, sociological and political science perspectives. In particular, the current shift from US-Japan bilateral relationship to Japan-China triangular relationship as the cornerstone of Japanese diplomacy will be closely investigated. The first part of the course aims to provide an academic framework for the study of Japanese diplomacy, such as the mechanism in foreign policy making, the interplay between diplomacy and domestic politics, and the rise of soft power and cultural diplomacy. The second part introduces Japan’s foreign policy with US, China, and ASEAN. The third part deals with traditional and non-traditional security issues as well as regionalism.

title: Japan in East Asian Politics: Visions of Regional Integration
description: This course aims to provide students with knowledge and framework of analysing the on-going process of regional integration in East Asia and Japan's role exercised in the process. The first part examines basic knowledge on world politics and movements related to regional integration, including the EU. The second part examines in details of various movements of regional integration in East Asia with a focus on Japan's intention and practices and provides perspectives of future visions of East Asia.

title: Introduction to Japanese Economy
description: This course introduces different aspects of the Japanese economy. Major topics include industrial structure, employment, trade, foreign investment and finance. Special emphasis will be put on the analysis of their structure, government policies and current problems.

title: The History of 20th Century Japan
description: This course explores modern Japan, which underwent perhaps the most striking transformation of any country in the modern world. Narrowly escaping colonization, Japan transformed into one of the most important imperial and economic powers in the world. Modern Japan is also doubly fascinating for a comparative take on the great themes of modern global history: the social upheavals and transformations of capitalism and democracy, the rise and fall of modern imperialism, the experience of total war, and the spread of a mass consumer culture. This course examines the invention of new traditions and the construction of a new national identity, the rise and fall of empire, the devastation of World War II, and the astonishing postwar economic growth and puzzling stagnation in contemporary times. This course explores how people in Japan have dealt with the dilemmas of modernity that challenge us all.
outcome: By the end of the semester, students will have achieved: (1) Understand the major dynamics and trends of modern Japanese history (2) Deepen their understanding of modern and contemporary Japanese society  (3) Learn to write logical and coherent historical papers
syllabus: Week 1: Course Introduction; Meiji Restoration This will explore the arrival of the “Black Ships” and the reasons behind the overthrow of the Shogunate.  Week 2: Civilization and Enlightenment This week deals with Japan’s Meiji-era cultural/intellectual Westernization.  Week 3: Constructing the Meiji State This week explores the creation of Japan’s new political structure and the fruits of Japan’s modern revolution.   Week 4: “Rich Nation, Strong Army,” and the Making of Japan’s Empire This week deals with the logic and goals of becoming an empire in the age of imperialism.  Week 5: State and Society in Japan’s Imperial Democracy This week investigates the move toward party leadership, and the linkages between state and society in Taishō era Japan.  Week 6: The Roaring ‘20s, and Tensions in Modern Life This week explores the tensions brought about by capitalism and Japanese modernity.  Week 7: Crisis of Capitalism and Empire This week explores the Great Depression and the “Manchurian Incident.”  Week 8: Japan at War This week deals with the “China Incident,” Japanese ultra-nationalism, and the move toward all-out war in the Asia-Pacific. It also deals with daily life during wartime.   Week 9: America’s Japan: Occupation and Aftermath This week studies the American Occupation of Japan and its aftermath.  Week 10: Cold War Realignments and the Conservative Political Resurgence This week highlights the remarkable conservative resurgence in Japan, and its battles with the progressive left.   Week 11: Postwar Economy and Society This week deals with the growth of a middle class and meritocratic society in the postwar years, and the remarkable “economic miracle.”  Week 12: A New Global Power? This week discusses the Plaza Accord, the Japanese economic bubble, and the birth of Japan as a new global power in the 1980s.  Week 13: The Lost Decades, 3.11, and Beyond This week has students cover important issues from the last 25 years of Japanese society.

title: The Construction of Japanese Ethnic and Cultural Identity
description: Though extensively influenced by ancient China, Japan has developed into one of the world’s most distinctive cultures. Japan’s remote geographic location made it possible for changes to come relatively slowly, and except for the postwar reform, most innovations resulted from the voluntary adoption of foreign cultures rather than external pressure. This course discusses how Japanese civilization, i.e. the Yamato nation, and the Japanese language were formed. How Japanese society arose through the localization of foreign cultures will be one of the major themes covered. Efforts will be made to identify nation-wide characteristics, if any, and investigate how they were cultivated over the centuries. Special attention will be paid to the similarities that can be found between the two major social reforms in modern Japanese history, i.e. the Meiji Restoration and postwar reform, and to the question of how these reforms influence Japan society today.
outcome: 1) to develop a proper understanding of Japanese culture from a cultural historical point of view;  2) to properly articulate different topics with relevant historical contexts of Japan;  3) to critically examine popular and yet controversial theories and/or perceptive frameworks for analyzing Japanese culture; and   4) to understand the specificity and universality of Japanese culture.

title: Japanese Youth Cultures in Asia
description: Youth cultures have played a critical role in shaping Japanese public attitudes and debates, consumer movements, and institutions in the postwar period. Japanese youth-oriented popular cultures are currently reshaping the cultural landscape across much of Asia. This course explores Japan's youth cultures and introduces the diversity of youth experiences in Japan. It further allows students to explore the influence of Japanese youth cultures in other Asian societies. The course encourages students to compare youth cultures in Japan with that of China, Hong Kong, and North America. The course will also consider the rise of transnational youth cultures based on movements of people, ideas, and images across national borders. It will explore the emergence of a Japan influenced youth popular culture in Asia as well as the particular local contexts in which the experiences of youth take on meanings for individuals.

title: Anthropology of Japanese Popular Culture
requirements: Prerequisite: JASP1090
description: This course offers an advanced seminar on Japanese popular and mass culture from anthropological perspectives. Thus this is not a survey course of different kinds of popular culture in Japan, but rather this course requires us to theoretically engage in social theories of popular/mass culture and analyze interpretations of meanings and forms of particular “popularly massified” socio-cultural phenomena in Japan.The course first provides literature on the major classical and critical theories of the “culture industry” in Europe as well as the formation of mass society in Japan. Next, we will analyze the forms and meanings of the diverse, popularly massified culture of production and consumption by examining anthropological works on Japan. Specifically, this course examines the issues of popular culture and mass culture through four different spheres: culture industries, media consumption, material culture and fandom, and globalization. Through analyzing these four spheres, the course also traces the thematic issues of gender, class, and cultural politics in the context of modernization and globalization. These issues provide the underlying structure and symbols that demonstrate how anthropologists approach a particular representation of complex popularized cultural movements under late capitalism.
outcome: By the end of the course students will be able to demonstrate knowledge of social theories and approaches to popular/mass culture and the culture industry. Students will also be able to construct analytical essays, give power-point presentations, and lead academic discussions.

title: World War Two on Japanese, Chinese and American Screens
description: This course aims to explore the possible motivations and political backgrounds underlying the production of films that are related to WWII in East Asia, following the end of the Cold War, that is, during and after the 1990s. The intention is to analyze whether the demise of the Cold War has provided a more favorable time for Japan, China and the US to re-examine WWII in a fresh light. The year 1990 marks a watershed for geopolitics. In that immediately prior to and after 1990, the world witnessed many historical events still thought of as the most significant in recent history, even today. Such events as regards East Asia include the Tiananmen Incident, the burst of Japan’s bubble economy, the disintegration of the USSR and the rise of China. Security concerns among China, Japan and the US changed following 1990 in that Russia is no longer thought of as being a common threat of such primary importance as was the case with its predecessor state, the USSR. There is today a renewed sense of nationalistic assertiveness that can be seen in disputes in and amongst Japan, China and the US over history, territories, military expansion and in conflict over trade between these economic giants. At the same time, in the last twenty years, there have been frequent productions of movies related to WWII in East Asia, on events where differing views of history cause controversy, such as the Nanjing Massacre, Pearl Harbor and Hiroshima. There is therefore importance in investigating to what extent these movies are a reflection of such nationalistic sentiment, as well as the extent to which the WWII theme in filmmaking for a popular market is a tool for groups harboring specific political and ideological agendas. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. Students are required to choose a related topic at the beginning of the course and present his/her ideas in the last two lessons. Based on the presentation, students are required to submit a paper of about 3,000 words in the end of the semester, indicating their appreciation and understanding of the lecture materials and required readings.
outcome: 1. be familiar with the political influence in the formation of popular culture, in particular why the images and narratives of WWII continue to play such a significant role in shaping public consciousness and people’s senses of identity 2. be familiar with the Japanese, Chinese and American historical collective consciousness in respect of WWII in East Asia 3. be able to contextualize and analyze selected movies and present a well-organized analysis in a written or oral presentation 4. be able to make connections between the past and present phenomena of the world
syllabus: Lesson 1: Orientation This lesson introduces the objectives, significances and learning approaches of the course.  Lesson 2 and 3: Japan’s Contested Views on War Responsibilities These two lessons explore how the Japanese reinforce and overemphasize their image as the victim of WWII; and on the other hand, how they address the war responsibilities of Emperor Hirohito and of their own country.  Lesson 4 and 5: Japanese and Chinese Representations of the Tokyo Trials These two lessons discuss how the Tokyo Trials are used as a channel through which to express anti-Americanism by some Japanese and Chinese movies.  Lesson 6 and 7: Nanjing Massacre and the Politics of Memories These two lessons examine how the Nanjing Massacre is politicized in a self-righteousness manner; and with a view to national mythmaking by many Chinese, Japanese and Americans.  Lesson 8 and 9: Political Agenda of CCP’s Commemorations These two lessons investigate how the Chinese Communist Party uses anniversaries and commemorations to promote their political messages.  Lesson 10 and 11: Heroism/Anti-Herosim in Post-911 American Cinema These two lessons analyze how heroism in American WWII movies has been transformed before and after the 911 Incident.   Lesson 12 and 13: Presentation of Students Students are required to present their topics and ideas in a 20-minute oral presentation with the use of power point.

title: Japanese Language and Society
requirements: Pre-requisite: JASP1040 or 2460 or 2480 or equivalent competence in Japanese.
description: This course explores both linguistic structures and sociolinguistic features of the Japanese language. The first half of the course will discuss sociolinguistic features in Japanese language such as the history of linguistic exchanges in the kanji (Chinese character) and lexicon between China and Japan among other case studies, application of linguistic politeness expressions and word formation. The second half of the course will discuss the major linguistic features in Japanese language such as its grammatical structures and semantic features in the Japanese language. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course. This course is designed for students who have completed elementary Japanese language courses and are interested to know more about the structure of the Japanese language and its sociolinguistic characteristics. At the completion of the course, students will have gained a better understanding of the structure of the Japanese language in general situations and will have learned how to apply language usage according to Japanese linguistic social norms.
outcome: 1 Students should acquire knowledge of the Japanese language structure  (i.e. sentence structure, characteristics of words and sound system)   2 Students should be able to describe the major characteristics of kanji, kanji words and loanwords in the Japanese   language   3 Students should be able to explain the characteristics and usage of the linguistic politeness in the Japanese   language   4 Students should be able to explain the main characteristics of the lexicon and word formation in Japanese   language   5 Students should acquire knowledge of syntactic and semantic structures in Japanese language
syllabus: Topic 1 Introduction to the structure of Japanese language In this section, the structure of the Japanese language will be discussed. It analyzes sentence structure, characteristics of words and sound systems in the Japanese language.  Topic 2 The development of kanji, kanji words and loanwords in the Japanese language In this section, the historical overview of kanji in Japanese language will be discussed. Various types of reading (goon, kanon and tôon – different forms of reading in Japanese) in Japanese kanji will be introduced. In addition, the history of how kanji words and loanwords are developed in the Japanese language will be discussed.  Topic 3 Expressions of linguistic politeness in the Japanese language In this section, the category and various forms of phrases expressing linguistic politeness will be discussed. It includes honorific expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.  Topic 4 Lexicon and words formation in the Japanese language In this section, the word type and word formation in Japanese language will be discussed. Special attention will be given to:   a. compound words  b. onomatopoeia (words signifying sounds and gestures)  Topic 5 Syntax in the Japanese language  In this section, the syntax structure in Japanese language will be discussed. Some of the highlighted items include:  a. tense and aspectual system  b. verb classification  c. “Mondaina Nihongo” (problematic Japanese usage)   Topic 6 Semantics in Japanese language In this section, the semantic structure in Japanese language will be discussed. Methodology such as semantic analysis, differentiation of connotative meaning and denotative meaning, and idiomatic expressions will be introduced.

title: Japanese Philosophy
description: This course aims to understand and analyze Japanese philosophy, which is an important topic for reflecting on the roots of Japanese intellectual history and contemporary philosophical debates. Three areas will be discussed: 1) Japanese intellectual traditions such as those found in Buddhism, Confucianism and Shinto/Native Studies thought; 2) modern Japanese philosophers such as Nishida Kitaro, Kuki Shuzo and Watsuji Tetsuro; and 3) contemporary Japanese thought: Karatani Kojin, Post-311 philosophy, etc.

title: Popular Religions in China, Japan and Korea
description: This course explores the East Asian philosophical and religious traditions of Confucianism, Daoism, and Buddhism both from an internal perspective – how did each tradition represent its own values, goals, practices and methods of devotion – and external perspectives – how did the traditions spread across the East Asian subcontinent, assimilate with traditional cultural norms, and influence art and architecture. In addition to these so-called “three teachings,” we also discuss popular religion in South-east Asia, new combinatory religions such as Aum Shinrikyo and Cao Đài, and the impact of East Asian religious ideas on the West. We will also address religion in modern times, understanding how traditions continue to carve out roles for themselves in a secular world.

title: Japanese Dialectology
requirements: Prerequisite: students should have one year studying experience in Japan or equivalent competence in Japanese.
description: Although Japanese language learners usually take the “standard language” of Japanese as the learning target, there are many dialects in Japan and they can represent the characteristics of culture in that particular area. This course introduces the structure of dialect by comparing the differences between the “standard language” and one representative example of Japanese dialects: the Kansai dialect. Students will learn how Kansai dialect reflects the culture and customs of the Kansai area through the perspectives of sociolinguistics. This course will use multi-media resources such as novels, T.V. soap dramas as teaching materials to illustrate the daily usage of the Kansai dialect.
outcome: 1. Students are expected to be able to identify and describe the characteristics of the language usage in Japanese media by studying the Kansai dialect which is one of the most well-known representative dialects in Japan.  2. Students are expected to be able to identify various types of dialects by comparing the differences among various dialects and the standard language.   3. Students are expected to be able to use the approach of sociolinguistic analysis and find out how culture influence the language usage.

title: Advanced Spoken Japanese
requirements: Prerequisite: One year of study in Japan or equivalent competence in Japanese
description: The course aims to enhance both speaking and listening abilities. Selected readings on contemporary Japanese or local social issues will be used to practice the expressions and exchange of ideas. Classroom activities will include exchanging ideas, discussion, speech, etc. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  ・discuss some abstract contents in Japanese.  ・discuss topics in Japanese not only in daily life level but also in business level for the future career.  ・make discussion supported with evidence.
syllabus: In order to achieve this goal, this course is divided into three stages. In the first stage, students are required to present their points of views with reasoning after given a topic without referring to any materials. In this stage, students will be asked to be paired-up. They have to try to tell their points of views. and at the same time, they learn other’s opinions as well.   In the second stage, students will be asked to find subjective materials to support their objective ideas. They are asked to collect information that they need to support their thoughts and their partners are asked to do the same in order to argue their point of views with facts and references.   In the final stage, by using what have been learnt in the first and second stages, students will be asked to debate on abstract topics such as "Environmental Protection and Urban Development", "pros and cons of surrogate mother system" and " Problem of male and female students living together in the college dorm". Debate topics will be discussed and chosen by students so as to increase their interests and motivation on the course.

title: Japanese Language and Classical Japanese Literature
requirements: Students should have fulfilled either one of the followings:1) Completed JASP2460 and a language course coded JASP3000 or above, or;2) Passed in Japanese Language Proficiency Test Level 2 or above or equivalent; or ;3) have studied in Japan for a year.
description: Why is it that the same kanji can be pronounced in different ways? Why is it that some colours are expressed as adjectives whereas others as nouns? Why are there so many exceptions to Japanese grammatical rules? To answer these questions, we will study the cultural encounter between China and Japan, the kokufu or Japanese-style culture, the establishment of noble society in ancient times, and the history of Japanese literature. We will also study waka or Japanese poetry, which constitutes the core of Japanese literature. Students will sample poems from the three most famous poetry collections—Manyoshu, Kokinshu and Shin-Kokinshu—to gain a better understanding of Japanese views on nature, philosophy, religion and ethnics which underlie Japanese aesthetics. The course will help students gain insights into present-day Japan by studying its roots in Heian literature and culture. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration.

title: Field Research-Based Project II
description: This course enables students to assemble and analyse research materials collected during their year of study in Japan or their third year of study when they take the local study scheme. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors in their final year of attendance.The Field-Research Based Project, a requirement for all JAS major students, is completed over the course of four years. Preparation for the project begins in year one and year two when students take JAS1010, JAS1050, and JAS1090. In these courses, students gain familiarity with contemporary Japanese politics, economy, culture and society. Students also learn to identify and evaluate academic arguments, locate academic sources, cite sources properly, and identify and assess basic social science and humanities research methods. In the third-year of study, students decide on their research topic and methods, and appropriately apply research methods to collect data for the project. Students who are in the fourth year of study, should have completed data collection and should be writing the paper. Students should have made efforts to speak, read, and write Japanese to achieve their research aims. Students are expected to have used Japanese for activities such as requesting assistance, conducting interviews, creating questionnaires, surveying media sources, and conducting literature reviews. The final-year project completed during the required courses JAS4601 and JAS4602 is thus the final product of the previous three years’ of preparation in both Japanese studies and Japanese language.Students are also required to sit for the Japanese Proficiency test (N1) before they graduate which is the requirement of the course JASP4602.
outcome: Students complete their research paper based on the data they collected during their year in Japan, and using the skills and knowledge attained during year one. Students are expected to (a) become knowledgeable about and critically analyze a specific topic in Japanese studies, (b) master the skills of researching and writing a research paper in English, and (c) gain proficiency in communicating the results of data collection and analysis.  Skills learned through the final-year project are transferable to their future workplaces and graduate school work. In job interviews, job applications, on their resumes, and in graduate school applications, JAS graduates who have successfully completed the project may be able to state the following:  1. They are capable of planning, developing, and implementing a long-term (two-year) project.  2. They are capable of approaching people to make new contacts and creating networks.  3. They are capable of collecting experts’ research results written in Japanese, Chinese, and English. They are capable of analyzing this material, making reasoned conclusions, and clearly communicating the results of your analysis orally and in writing. 4. They are capable of collecting original data, analyzing, and communicating the results of their analysis.
syllabus: Students will submit a mid-year draft of the paper, approximately 15 to 25 pages. The final paper, approximately 30 to 40 pages will be sumitted before the end of the semester. In addition, students will make an oral presentation on a chosen date.

title: Japanese Linguistics
requirements: Prerequisite: JASP1030 or 1460 or equivalent competence in Japanese.
description: Students are required to attend a placement test before course registration. The aim of this course is to enable students to acquire a general understanding of different aspects of the Japanese language. The contents include: (1) the sound system of Japanese; (2) Chinese characters and Kanas; (3) a brief introduction of theories on grammar; and (4) structure of modern Japanese.

title: Error Analysis of Hong Kong Japanese Learners
requirements: Prerequisite: students should have one year studying experience in Japan or passed Japanese Proficiency Test Level 2 or equivalent competence in Japanese.
description: This course introduces Japanese morphological and syntactical features through studying the common errors made by Japanese learners whose first language is Chinese. Students will learn to describe the reasons for the errors and analyze the characteristics of errors by comparing the structures of Chinese and Japanese language. This course will also explore the importance of these features with the aid of research findings of linguistics and Japanese language teaching. This course is designed for advanced Japanese learners. Students will be able to explain both the causes and the problems of these common morphological and syntactical errors. They are also expected to have basic techniques for analyzing morphological and syntactical features by linguistics and Japanese language teaching know-how.

title: Theory and Research Methods
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This core course is designed to prepare students to conduct postgraduate research in Japanese Studies. It introduces key conceptual and methodological approaches from different disciplines. Students are encouraged to critically evaluate various approaches and consider how they may be integrated for their particular research projects. The course teaches the analytical skills and methodological tools that will allow students to develop and execute a research project. These skills include research design, data collection, analysis and developing writing strategies.
outcome: At the conclusion of the course, students will be able to: 1) identify and analyze the main methodological and theoretical approaches adopted in the study of Japanese society and culture in recent decades.  2) articulate the basic trends in the social development of modern Japan.

title: Special Topics in Japanese Popular Culture
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: The course introduces existing literature, approaches, sources and issues in the study of Japanese popular culture in Japan, Asia and the world. Issues in cultural globalization, hybridity, cultural colonialism, orientalism, postmodernism, Japanization, Asianization and localization will be discussed. Ethnographical survey and fieldwork-based projects are also used as parts of the methodological training. Specific topics such as sushi, video games or television dramas are chosen for in-depth investigation according to the academic interest of students.

title: Special Topics in Japanese Popular Culture in Asia
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This course investigates the popularization, Japanization and localization of Japanese popular culture in Asia in the context of cultural globalization. Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore, three centers of Japanese popular culture boom in Asia, are chosen as subjects for close investigation. Ethnographical survey and fieldwork-based projects are also used as parts of the methodological training.

title: Special Topics in Sino-Japanese Relations
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This study introduces basic primary sources and secondary references about Sino-Japanese relations from past to present. Japanese, Chinese and English sources are used. Some knowledge of reading Japanese and Chinese is required. Students are trained to make use of primary and secondary materials for research in this area. Students will do a project or research paper on a selective topic in Sino-Japanese relations (including Japan-Hong Kong and Japan-Taiwan).

title: Special Topics in Japan-Hong Kong Relations
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This is a multi-disciplinary course that aims to promote scholarship on the developing research area in Japan-Hong Kong relations. Basic sources and literature in Japanese, English and Chinese are assigned for reading and fieldwork-based projects are conducted as practical training in writing and methodology. Students should have at least intermediate reading ability in Japanese.

title: Special Topics in the Anthropology of Japan
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This course explores methods and approaches used by anthropologists in studying Japan. The course provides students with an anthropological framework for research on Japan. It introduces village studies, urban studies, and recent studies of popular culture, gender and mass society. The course will also introduce theoretical approaches and concepts used by anthropologists studying Japan. Students will be encouraged to focus on a particular aspect of Japanese society using selected anthropological approaches.
outcome: At the conclusion of the course, students will be able to: 1) to identify and critically analyze the main methodological and theoretical approaches adopted in the study of Japanese society and culture by anthropologists in recent decades.  2) use anthropological approaches to discuss basic trends in the social development of modern Japan.

title: Special Topics in Gender Studies of Japan
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This course introduces approaches to studies of gender in Japan. The focus will be primarily on sociological and anthropological studies of gender. The course takes a historical perspective, encouraging students to consider how and why ideological constructions of gender have changed over time in specific social, political and economic contexts. It considers the relationship between social ideals, institutional structures and everyday experiences of gender. The course also examines current gender relations and roles in a variety of arenas of life such as families, corporations, communities, political groups, schools, and in the mass media.

title: The Japanese Political Economy
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This course is designed to provide fundamental knowledge for understanding various aspects of the economy, politics and business practices in contemporary Japan. It analyses key aspects of the Japanese political economy employing contending paradigms in the field of international and comparative political economy. By taking this course students will become familiar with major paradigmatic approaches in the study of Japan and will acquire a critical framework for independently assessing new information and data on contemporary Japanese economics, politics, and business.

title: Special Topics in the Japanese Political Economy
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This course investigates major debates as related to the Japanese political economy in the global age. It is designed to enhance a theoretical and empirical understanding of the Japanese political economy and business at advanced level. It incorporates the necessary tools for a critical analysis of the existing political-economic system by familiarizing students with advanced theories, research design and methodology. By taking this course, students will gain an in-depth knowledge of Japanese politics, economics and business utilizing appropriate approaches and analytical tools.

title: Special Topics in Language Acquisition in Japanese
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This course introduces a survey of the quantitative and qualitative research literature on the acquisition of first language acquisition among Japanese children and second language among the Japanese adult learners. Research carried out in both experimental and natural settings will be examined in light of modern linguistic theory.

title: Special Topics in Cross Linguistic Research
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: Selected linguistic differences between Japanese and other languages including English will be introduced in this course. Cross-linguistic variation in phonology, syntax and semantics will be analyzed to compare languages from the perspectives of Language Typology and Universal Grammar.

title: Special Topics in Linguistic Research and Japanese Language Teaching
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies
description: This course examines different issues in linguistic research that is particularly applicable to foreign language teaching and learning. Focus is put on the interface of theoretical analysis and their implications for Japanese language teaching and learning as a foreign language.
outcome: (1) Students will be able to have an overview of those key linguistic research topics related to teaching Japanese as a foreign language.   (2) Students will be able to apply the methodologies and findings from those linguistic studies discussed in this course to their own linguistic study.

title: Special Topics in Japanese Studies
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course will focus on specific topics in Japanese studies that are not covered in the regular course offering. These topics will reflect academic needs/interests and faculty expertise.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to achieve the learning goals stated by the instructor who will be an expert in the course topic.

title: Special Research Topics in Japanese Studies
requirements: For students in the Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D Programme in Japanese Studies
description: This course will focus on specific research topics in Japanese studies that are not covered in the regular course offering. These topics will reflect students’ academic needs/interests and faculty expertise.

title: Teaching Japanese as a Second Language
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course introduces and discusses various concepts in teaching Japanese as a second language which include course design, the procedures of handling classroom activities, the proper usage of teaching materials and teaching tools, method of assessment of students, etc. These discussions are essential to students who will pursue their career goals in Japanese language teaching upon graduation. Moreover, the course will also examine methods used in teaching foreign language with a focus on Japanese language education.
outcome: 1.Students should acquire the technique of course design and teaching plan preparation. 2.Students should be able to apply various methods to teach the four essential skills in language acquisition, namely, reading, writing, listening and speaking. 3.Students should be able to explain those significant grammatical points in an easy-to-understand way. 4.Students should acquire the technique of classroom management. 5.Students should be able to apply the cultural elements to assist foreign language teaching.

title: Japanese Communication through Language and Culture
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course explores Japanese communication patterns and the relationship between Japanese language, society, and culture. The course considers how the use of language reflects social contexts and human relationships. It also explores the factors that shape the success or failure of communicating in Japan, and how Japanese communication patterns compare with those of other cultures.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to: (i) Understanding how the Japanese language interrelates with culture and society; (ii) Exploring the differences and similarities between Japanese and their own language (e.g., Chinese); (iii) Applying the gained knowledge to understand people in Japan from linguistics and cultural perspectives.

title: Japanese Management Systems and Practice
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course enables students to develop a solid understanding of Japanese management systems and practices. The topics covered include cultural issues in business, keiretsu systems, human resource management practice, and corporate governance, and strategies in relation to global trends. Class meetings will consist of a mix of lecture and class discussion and presentations on the selected topics.

title: Tradition and Modernity in Contemporary Japan
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course aim at analyzing the relationship between traditional culture and modern society in Japan. It explores key cultural and social concepts in historical contexts, and considers how ideas and institutions have changed over time.
outcome: 1) Students are expected to gain an understanding of the relationship between historical social-cultural institutions and modern formations of Japanese life including work, family, gender roles, marriage, leisure, and religion.  2) Students will be able to identify and critically assess different ways in which traditional culture is interpreted in modern Japan.  2) Students will be able to critically assess different approaches to understanding Japanese society and culture.  3) Students will have improved their academic essay writing and research skills.

title: Chinese-Japanese Interpretation and Translation
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course aims to enable students proficient in Japanese and Chinese (mainly Putonghua but also Cantonese) to critically understand interpreting professions in terms of language, cognition, and ethics, and develop their practical techniques in interpreting Chinese into Japanese, suitable to prospective or ongoing professional interpreters as well as upper advanced language learners wishing to obtain in-depth knowledge of both languages. Different types of discourses will be used to acquire basic but versatile skills of consecutive interpretation by stages. Trainings cover retention, anticipation, paraphrasing, reproduction, information precession, note taking, sight translation, and possibly simple simultaneous interpretation. Special attention is drawn to contrasting structural and socio-cultural between Chinese and Japanese languages.

title: Theory and Methods in Japanese Studies
requirements: For students in Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course is intended to introduce and broaden the understanding of contemporary Japanese society from the modern period to the contemporary period. By introducing some of the theories and methodological approaches that have been used to examine Japanese society, students will learn, and critically discuss perspectives of history, sociology, anthropology and cultural studies and media analyses. Moreover, utilizing a variety of readings, lectures, and film, students will engage in a multi-level analysis of contemporary Japan.
outcome: The course has a number of major learning outcomes. (1) Students are expected to critically discuss Japanese society using a variety of theories and methodological approaches. (2) Students are expected to be able to clarify and articulate thoughtful and well-founded opinions from a comparative perspectives. (3) Students are expected to develop the ability to engage critically in academic discussions through weekly contributions to in-class discussions and presentations. (4) Students are expected to develop their research skills through a short-term research project that includes a written assignment and in-class presentation.

description: This is an introductory course in Japan’s modern history. The course covers the period from 1600, when the Tokugawa Shogunate began its two-and-half-century rule over Japan, to 1945, when the Asia-Pacific War ended with Japan’s surrender. title: Anthropology of Japan
requirements: For students Articulated M.Phil-Ph.D in Japanese Studies or MA in Japanese Studies
description: This course examines major anthropological approaches to Japanese society and culture. These approaches include those that view Japan as a cultural whole such as the cultural and personality paradigm, ethnographic approaches, modernization and development theories, globalization theories, structural approaches, neoMarxism, feminism, postmodernism, and cultural studies approaches. Each week, lectures will introduce a particular approach to Japan, and the assigned readings will provide examples of that approach. Students will be asked to discuss the readings and the different approaches introduced in the lectures.
outcome: This course has the following outcomes: 1. Students will be able to identify and discuss different anthropological approaches to Japan.  2. Students will be able to analyze ideas discussed in this course to reflect critically upon different approaches they encounter in approaching Japan. 3. Students will be able to reflect on larger questions of meaning and perspective. How do different approaches reflect different realities of the time? As understanding of societies constantly change through time, how do we interpret truths? How can we know truths if approaches and even conclusions may be products of the time and of the background of the researcher?
